Award.AwardTitle: US-Namibia Planning Visit: Building a Research Collaboration on the Effects of Non-rainfall Input on Dryland Ecosystem Functions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project, led by PI Lixin Wang of Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI), will conduct planning meetings and collect and analyze preliminary data to develop a project that will assess the effects of non-rainfall water input on dryland ecosystem functions. The planning visit, preliminary data collection and future research efforts will take place in the Namib Desert, Namibia. Dr. Wang will collaborate with Dr. Mary Seely of the Gobabeb Research and Training Center in the Namib-Naukluft National Park, located in the Namib Desert.

The research effort that will result from this planning visit will test the hypothesis that non-rainfall moisture contributes significantly to desert ecosystem function. Equally importantly, the research will attempt to identify the source areas of fog/dew using stable isotope analyses and will assess how much fog and dew contribute to ecosystem function. With lower future rainfall predicted across drylands globally, the role of non-rainfall moisture input may become even more valuable, and assessing the sources of fog/dew inputs will allow modeling to determine how those inputs may change with climate change.

The planning visit will include identification of specific sampling sites and collection of fog, dew, precipitation and soil moisture samples in three ecosystems near Gobabeb in the Naukluft Park area of the Namib Desert. The team will also meet with ministry officials to explore the potential for additional permits for sampling on non-park land closer to the shore where fog may be more frequent. The planning visit will also assess the ability of the Gobabeb Training and Research Center to support longer-term sampling efforts. Proof-of-concept stable isotope analyses will be conducted on the samples collected during the planning visit to verify that fog/dew isotope signatures can be differentiated from other moisture sources and therefore form the foundation for future water source modeling efforts.

This project also has interesting and valuable broader impacts. The planning visit team includes an education outreach coordinator from the IUPUI Center for Earth and Environmental Science (CEES) who will initiate an education module for third through ninth graders focusing on the physical geography of the Namib Desert, the changes taking place in this ecosystem and the implications for dryland ecosystems globally. This education module will be fully developed in the full proposal that the team plans to prepare based on this planning visit. In addition, a graduate student will participate in the planning visit, initial data collection, data analyses and preparation of the full proposal, providing that student with a valuable professional development opportunity. The PI also plans to develop a new course on Desert Environments for senior undergraduates and graduate students at IUPUI using case studies based on this project, which will expose other students to the international contexts of their studies. Undergraduates are expected to be involved in the research that would be supported by a later full proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Undoubtedly rainfall is the major water input form for most ecosystems in the world and is essential for maintaining ecosystem functions. However, in many coastal regions, inland deserts and mountainous areas, non-rainfall water inputs (e.g., fog and dew) can be recurrent meteorological phenomena that can exceed annual rainfall. Unfortunately, these non-rainfall water inputs are often the least studied components of the hydrological system although they are crucial to sustaining life in water scarce ecosystems, drylands. There are many unanswered questions in non-rainfall water research such as 1) what are the sources of the non-rainfall water inputs (local vs. advected), 2) what is the significance of each non-rainfall water inputs component to the ecosystem, and 3) how will climate change impact fog or dew dominated ecosystems. The goal of this project was to establish a new international collaboration in a unique fog-dominated system in Namibia and collect preliminary data for developing a full proposal to comprehensively evaluate the effects of non-rainfall input (i.e., fog and dew) on dryland ecosystem functions.

During the course of this project, we made a total of five trips to Namibia from July 2014 to July 2017, with additional support from EAR-1554894. In this project, among other interesting research work, we uniquely utilized the isotopic compositions of δ18O, δ2H and δ17O to characterize different ecosystem pools and trace the origins of fog and dew to the ecosystem pools within the Namib Desert fog-zone. For the first time, we show that although advective fog may have defined the extent of the fog-zone, there are at least two additional fog types occurring in this area (radiation and mixed fog). We also demonstrate the same for the dew formation. The results emphasize the role of vegetation in redistributing groundwater via evapotranspiration and contributing to non-rainfall water formation. Therefore the role of groundwater in in such ecosystems may be often overlooked and grossly under-estimated. Contrary to expectation, localized fog occurred more frequently than advective fog and could be indicating a receding fog-zone boundary. We also demonstrated for the first time that fog and dew could be differentiated based on the δ'17O vs. δ'18O relationship. Three research articles coming out of this project were featured in the journal cover and received numerous media attentions.

As part of this project, three graduate students were trained in the laboratory and field on methods of soil moisture instrumentation and isotope measurement and modeling. The fieldwork served as the basis for one master thesis and two PhD dissertations in the Department of Earth Sciences at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis. The master student successfully finished his study (with two peer-reviewed publications) and moved on to a PhD position. Both PhD students are in progress. Because of the outstanding academic achievements of the two PhD students, one received the President Diversity Fellowship and another was nominated for the John Edwards fellowship, which is the most prestigious award across all campuses in Indiana University. The PI’s lab also hosted three minority high school students for two months each summer through the Indianapolis Project SEED program during the project period. Part of the students’ training involved using the laser isotope instrument to measure rainfall and fog isotopic compositions. The high school students presented their results at the Project SEED Symposium. The PI’s group has been involved in organizing several sessions for the 2014-2016 AGU Fall meetings. These sessions aim to expand our understanding in dryland ecohydrology and will play an important role in defining the future direction of dryland ecohydrology. The PI also chaired an education poster session aiming at enhancing the experienced-based learning in the field of environmental sciences in 2015 and 2016. Besides the domestic impact, while in Africa doing field work, the graduate student working in this project was invited to present our research work to the local communities. The seminar serves as an education tool to the local community members, who will help inform the remaining community about the hydrological consequences of climate change. Field activities have allowed for the hire of several members of the local community, which provided first hand research experiences and knowledge for local people. Additionally, we facilitated our local research partner institution to host primary and secondary students who are given a tour of the stations activities and research projects to encourage more Namibian students into science thus reaching a wider local audience.
